en: Walking along the slope in the silence of the great landscape, a murmur is gradually heard. At first imperceptible, this murmur grows as you get closer to the Moulins de la Foux... The landscape of garrigue crushed by heat and silence suddenly changes into a spectacle of unexpected chaos of huge rocks, deafening noises, sea spray and coolness... The waters of the Vis literally gush forth from the bowels of the earth with a surprising and invigorating, but also somewhat disturbing ardour. The spectacle is grandiose in the face of the resurgence since the arrival of Blandas. Roaring in the bowels of the Causses La Vis is born in the Gard Cévennes, on the southern slope of the Lingas Massif, is lost near Alzon and resurfaces at La Foux with a flow 100 times greater because it is loaded with the infiltration waters of the Causses de Blandas, Campestre and Larzac. As the crow flies, 6 km separate the loss of the Vis from its resurgence, but the extent of its catchment area is much greater. The route of the Vis has been the subject of numerous expeditions by geologists since the beginning of the 20th century. One thing is certain, the Foux is the most important "source" of the Grands Causses. With a flow rate rarely less than 1m3/s, the Vis delivers a force that used to drive the mills used to grind the grains harvested on the adjacent Causses. As early as the 11th century, mills were set up in these places and Man had already tamed this nature. However, on several occasions, during major floods, the mills were damaged or literally washed away and then rebuilt afterwards. It is said that in 1870, the millers had to take refuge on the roofs. An umpteenth flood in 1907 led to the definitive abandonment of the mills until their restoration in 2000 by the town hall of Vissec within the framework of the Operation Great Site of the Cirque de Navacelles
fr: Cheminant le long du versant dans le silence du grand paysage, un murmure se fait progressivement entendre. D’abord imperceptible, celui-ci va grandissant au fur et à mesure que l’on se rapproche des Moulins de la Foux... Le paysage de garrigue écrasé par la chaleur et le silence se change soudain en spectacle d’un chaos inattendu d’énormes rochers, de bruits assourdissants, d’embruns et de fraicheur... Les eaux de la Vis jaillissent littéralement des entrailles de la terre avec une fougue surprenante et vivifiante, mais aussi quelque peu inquiétante. Le spectacle est grandiose face à la résurgence depuis l’arrivée de Blandas. Grondement dans les entrailles des Causses La Vis naît dans les Cévennes gardoises, sur le versant Sud du Massif du Lingas, se perd près d’Alzon et ressurgit à la Foux avec un débit 100 fois supérieur car elle est chargée des eaux d’infiltration des Causses de Blandas, de Campestre et du Larzac. À vol d'oiseau, 6 km séparent la perte de la Vis et sa résurgence mais l’étendue de son bassin d’alimentation est beaucoup plus grande. Le trajet de la Vis fait l’objet de nombreuses expéditions par des géologues depuis le début du XXe siècle. Une chose est certaine, la Foux est la plus importante « source » des Grands Causses. Avec un débit rarement inférieur à 1m3/s, la Vis délivre une force qui permettait autrefois d’actionner les moulins servant à moudre les grains récoltés sur les causses adjacents. Dès le XIe siècle, les moulins étaient implantés en ces lieux et l’Homme apprivoisait déjà cette nature. Mais à plusieurs reprises, lors de crues importantes, les moulins furent endommagés ou littéralement emportés par les eaux puis reconstruits par la suite. On raconte qu’en 1870, les meuniers durent se réfugier sur les toits. C’est une énième inondation en 1907 qui entraîna l’abandon définitif des moulins jusqu’à leur restauration en 2000 par la mairie de Vissec dans le cadre de l’Opération Grand Site du Cirque de Navacelles
Le Grondement des entrailles des Causses aux Moulins de La Foux - Vissec

hasBeenPublishedBy.schema:logo: https://www.tourismegard.com/Portals/2/Market-place/Le portail des pros du tourisme du Gard_fichiers/logo-Gard-Tourisme.jpg

en:
Walking along the slope in the silence of the great landscape, a murmur is gradually heard. At first imperceptible, it grows as we get closer to the Moulins de la Foux... The garrigue landscape, crushed by the heat and the silence, suddenly changes into an unexpected chaos of huge rocks, deafening noises, sea spray and freshness... The waters of the Vis literally gush out of the bowels of the earth with a surprising and invigorating, but also somewhat disturbing ardour. The spectacle is grandiose in front of the resurgence since the arrival of Blandas.
Rumbling in the bowels of the Causses

The Vis is born in the Cévennes Gardoises, on the southern slopes of the Lingas Massif, is lost near Alzon and resurfaces at La Foux with a flow 100 times greater because it is loaded with water from the Causses of Blandas, Campestre and Larzac. As the crow flies, 6 km separate the loss of the Vis and its resurgence but the extent of its catchment area is much greater. The route of the Vis has been the subject of numerous expeditions by geologists since the beginning of the 20th century. One thing is certain, the Foux is the most important "source" of the Grands Causses. With a flow rarely less than 1m3/s, the Vis delivers a force that used to drive the mills used to grind the grains harvested on the adjacent causses.
As early as the 11th century, mills were set up in these places and Man was already taming this nature. But on several occasions, during major floods, the mills were damaged or literally swept away by the waters and then rebuilt. It is said that in 1870, the millers had to take refuge on the roofs. It is an umpteenth flood in 1907 that led to the definitive abandonment of the mills until their restoration in 2000 by the town hall of Vissec within the framework of the Operation Great Site of the Cirque de Navacelles

Avec un débit rarement inférieur à 1m3/s, la Vis délivre une force qui permettait autrefois d’actionner les moulins servant à moudre les grains récoltés sur les causses adjacents.
Dès le XIe siècle, les moulins étaient implantés en ces lieux et l’Homme apprivoisait déjà cette nature.
